sub_topic: Using the Fourier transform to analyze the behavior of networks
message_1:
A network is modeled as a continuous-time signal given by the equation:

$x(t)= \begin{cases} 1, \quad 0 \leq t \leq 2 \\ 0, \quad t > 2 \end{cases}$

Determine the Fourier transform of the network signal $x(t)$.
message_2:
To find the Fourier transform of the network signal $x(t)$, we will use the following definition of the continuous-time Fourier transform:

$X(f) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x(t) e^{-j2\pi ft} dt$

Since $x(t)$ is non-zero only in the interval $0 \leq t \leq 2$, we can rewrite the integral as:

$X(f) = \int_{0}^{2} e^{-j2\pi ft} dt$

Now, we can solve the integral:

$X(f) = \left[-\frac{1}{j2\pi f} e^{-j2\pi ft}\right]_0^2$

$X(f) = -\frac{1}{j2\pi f} (e^{-j4\pi f} - 1)$

So, the Fourier transform of the network signal $x(t)$ is:

$X(f) = -\frac{1}{j2\pi f} (e^{-j4\pi f} - 1)$
